newsitem.title: CANADA: Fletcher talks continue, tension high.
newsitem.headline: Fletcher talks continue, tension high.

text.p: Negotiating under threat of a strike, contract talks between Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd and its unions continued Monday but a union official described them as very tense.
"We are still bargaining but things are in a very tense state," said Brian Payne, regional vice president for the Communication, Energy and Paperworkers union.
Union workers at the pulp and paper maker voted last month 96 percent in favor of a strike if necessary. They must give 10 days notice if they call a strike.
Payne said both sides were determined in their positions and it would likely be clearer by Tuesday whether the talks could make progress. He said he remains optimistic.
A Fletcher official was not immediately available for comment.

The two sides resumed negotiations last Friday and continued through the weekend, the first time they had met since talks collapsed in mid-June. They are seeking to reach a new contract to replace one that expired in April.
The 2,400 workers are represented by two unions. The main stumbling blocks have been the company's demand for an eight-year contract, 365-day-a-year operation and greater workplace flexibility.
Fletcher is majority owned by New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge Ltd.
